newsitem.title: USA: Alcoa says Suriname smelter still operating.
newsitem.headline: Alcoa says Suriname smelter still operating.

text.p: Alcoa's 30,000 tonnes per year Suralco aluminum smelter in Paramaribo, Suriname will operate on a day-by-day basis for the time being while a nearby alumina refinery remains crippled by a strike over pay, the company said.
Alcoa's Pittsburgh head office spokeswoman, Bonnie Cersosimo said workers at the alumina refinery went on strike on Monday and the plant was shut down Wednesday.
Refinery workers had been working without a contract since March 17.
"The smelter is operating on a day-by-day basis. We don't know how long we can keep it going," Cersosimo said. She was not aware of any preparations to shut it down.
There was also no indication how much alumina stocks were available at the smelter.
"We want to concentrate on an agreement and getting employees back to work," she added. "Discussions are occuring in terms of trying to resolve this."
Suralco owns the bauxite mine and aluminum smelter.
Suralco is wholly-owned by Alcoa World Alumina and Chemicals a 60/40 percent joint venture between Alcoa and Western Mining of Australia.
The alumina refinery is 55 percent owned by Alcoa and 45 percent by Billiton, part of South Africa's Gencor Ltd and produces 4,500 tonnes of alumina per day.
Cersosimo said only three percent of the refinery's alumina output is consumed by Suralco's smelter, the balance is sold to Suralco and Billiton customers.
"It's true at this moment that we have not notified customers of any force majeure," Cersosimo said.
Once the strike is over, it would only take a few days to start up the refinery again, Cersosimo added.
Some 1,900 people are employed at the refinery and smelter.
